qas.question: How many lumens can some high-power LEDs emit?
Up to how many densities have been achieved with LED power?
Why must High-power LEDs be mounted on a heat sink?
What will happen if the heat from a high-power LED is not removed?

answers.text: the device will fail in seconds

qas.question: What can one high-power LED replace?
How many lumens can some low-power LEDs emit?
Up to how many densities have never been achieved with LED power?
Why must High-power LEDs be mounted on a heat rise?
What will happen if the heat from a low-power LED is not removed?
What can one low-power LED replace?

context: High-power LEDs (HP-LEDs) or high-output LEDs (HO-LEDs) can be driven at currents from hundreds of mA to more than an ampere, compared with the tens of mA for other LEDs. Some can emit <a0_0><b5_0>over a thousand<b5_0/><a0_0/> lumens. LED power densities up to <a1_0><b6_0>300 W/cm2<b6_0/><a1_0/> have been achieved. Since overheating is destructive, the HP-LEDs must be mounted on a heat sink <a2_0>to <b7_0>allow for heat dissipation<b7_0/><a2_0/>. If the heat from a HP-LED is not removed, <a3_0>the <b8_0>device will fail in seconds<a3_0/>.<b8_0/> One HP-LED can often replace an <a4_0><b9_0>incandescent bulb<b9_0/> in a flashlight<a4_0/>, or be set in an array to form a powerful LED lamp.
